content.description: Start with right fingers jammed in the crack and press up the crack to gain bad slopers to the left.  Continue up and left to top out.
content.protection: 2+ pads.
content.location:
Just downstream from

Afro Bush

, left of

Party Trick

(

21 Guns

).

content.description:
Nice warmup slab left of

Garden Party

.
content.protection: 1-2 pads.
content.location: Bear Canyon Trail.

climbs.name: V9"ish" Arete
climbs.fa: Ned Harris stand start 200?, Ryan Sylven sit start 2011

content.description: Stand start the NW Arete is a good V5.  Sit start makes it V9 "ish"
content.protection: 2+ pads, spotter.
content.location: This is on Tier 2 just west of the large Grey Whale Boulder.

content.description: This is an awesome highball right off the Bear Canyon Trail. Start low on some big holds, and move up to a big ledge using some crimps and making some fun, big moves. Stand up on the ledge and then mantle over the top at 20+ feet.
content.protection: Pads. The hard moves are all towards the bottom, but you sure wouldn't want to blow the topout.
content.location:
This route is almost on the Bear Canyon Trail. It is just left off the trail (south) once the big boulders start to appear. It is on a rock called the Shelf Block and is East of

Garden Party

. You can't miss it.

content.description: Juggy roof problem, how you start is optional (toe hook or campus) the boulder itself is in good condition and is cleaned. Starts on the 2 most obvious holds in the middle, goes left to the juggy crack, then to the outer most holds and top out. Crux is the beginning depending on how you start.
content.protection: A couple of pads would be nice.
content.location: Down the canyon's north side on the "Panda's Den" Boulder.

content.description: On Tier 2, this route traverses in on slopers from the left and enters the topout of Bear Trap.
content.protection: Multiple pads and a spotter for the topout.
content.location: This is on the NE face of the Gray Whale Boulder.

content.description: The top out is a little bit sketchy and is also the crux. The problem is a good warm-up. Good problem.
content.protection: A few crashpads and a good spot, because the landing is a bit sketchy.
content.location: The boulder is in Bear Canyon.

content.description: Start standing, low on an undercling/sidepull complex, in the middle of the south face dihedral. Move up the dihedral, get a good stance then a high right foot, and then move up and back left to topout.
content.protection: It has a pretty flat landing and is kind of tall.
content.location:
Go up the Bear Canyon trail until you cross the creek. After a few switchbacks, a gully and a faint fall line of boulders leads to the north. About 10 minutes above the Jwiving Block (detailed in Bob Horan's "

Colorado Bouldering

" or "

Best of Boulder Bouldering

"), to the NE, you will stumble across this beautiful boulder.

content.description: The crux is the move when you have a pinch with your right hand and a sidepull with your left hand, then grabbing the crimp afterwards is difficult.
content.protection: Crashpads.
content.location: Start is at the bottom of the boulder.

content.description:
Nice, water polished bulge below

Afro Bush

with cool slopers.  SDS makes it more challenging.
content.protection: 1-2 pads.
content.location: Bear Canyon streambed.

content.description: Start on good rock and slab out to a high, dirty topout. This will get better with traffic.
content.protection: 2 pads.
content.location: This is right up the middle of the N Face of the Grey Whale.

content.description: Climb the face. Stand start low. The first few moves are probably the crux, though the middle and top require delicate climbing.
content.protection: Pads would be a good idea. This has some friable rock.
content.location:
It ascends the first main face just a few feet to the left of "

Shadow's Path

".

content.description:
Link up/variation.  Start on

Brazilian

SDS, do 1st move, then move left into crux of

Afro Bush

.  Maybe a touch harder than the standard start.
content.protection:
See

Afro Bush

.
content.location:
Afro Bush

grotto.

content.description: Sit start way under the roof on good holds. Move left to gain access to a thin seam that climbs out the steep roof to a juggy topout.
content.protection: 3 pads.
content.location:
This is on the seventh tier of boulders down the streambed from the

Hydrahedral

. (

Afro Bush

is on tier #3.)  There are many unlisted boulders/HARD projects in this gem of a canyon.

content.description:
This an obvious trailside dihedral.  After failing at the lip for many years, I came down it on a rope to clean the upper slab.  Judging from the amount of moss and lichen on all the upper holds, it's been a long time since its been ascended....much better now.  Go do it!

Apparently this has been done with 2 different exits.  We moved right up the arete to a good, right-hand, finger bucket to top out.  The other exit would involve going straight up the face on very bad holds...this version seems much harder.
content.protection: It has a flat landing (on trail), but it is highball enough that 3-4 pads are nice.
content.location: You can't miss it as you hike up the Bear Canyon trail.

content.description: Grab the rounded undercling with your right hand (turn your head and cough) then,  using a small edge for your left hand, pull on with bad feet.  A couple big moves with bad feet lead to an easier top out.
content.protection: 1 or more pads.
content.location: This is on the North side of the Bear Canyon Trail about 30 feet West of the Hydrahedral Boulder.  If you go straight North from the trail to the boulder, you shouldn't hit any poison ivy.

content.description:
This is a highball to the left of

Trixie's Trailside Treat

.  It started out pretty dirty, but it saw a few ascents October, 2010, so it's gotten a bit cleaner.  There are nice edges all the way with a balancy pebble move right before the lip....
content.protection: Highball!  The more pads the better.
content.location: It is on Trailhedral Rock on the Bear Canyon Trail.

content.description: This is fun.
content.protection: 2+ pads.
content.location: On Tier 2, climb the obvious flakes on the West side of The Grey Whale boulder.  If you are paying attention, you will see this from the trail, down in the trees.

content.description:
This is a nice problem consisting largely of crimpy moves with hard to find but okay feet. The topout might be the crux, as the top needs cleaning and doesn't provide great friction.

Start a couple of feet to the left of the nose of the boulder with your right hand on a good rail and your left hand on a thin crimp. Move up and right on a system of crimps before gaining a slopey right hand on the way to the topout.

I'm listing the FA as Steven Bogacz/unknown, because although I haven't been able to find any previous information on the boulder, I also find it hard to believe that something so close to the trail could have gone unclimbed, even though it is 3 miles down trail. I would gladly update this page if anyone has any information on it.
content.protection: This has a pretty clean landing zone, so a spotter and an optional crash pad are all that's needed.
content.location: The boulder is about 3 miles down the Bear Canyon Trail if you go into it from the NCAR/Mesa Trail side.

content.description: The crux is the top out. The middle part is the best. Fun problem. Good holds.
content.protection: There is a bit of a sketchy landing so use many crashpads and a good spot.

content.description:
Chossasaurus, likely done by Bob Horan years ago and left unnamed, is located on the highball, trailside boulder just past

Tears Overhang

. Climb the sheer, west-facing wall. Start on opposing sidepulls or a crimpy rail, work up to a chossy crimp (don't pull out) about 10 feet off the deck, then carefully climb the rails and crimps to the top. This is a killer line with exception of the choss crimp / sketchy landing.
content.protection: At least two pads, the landing is boulder strewn.

content.description: Not too bad. If there is a crux, it's the bottom part. The top can get a little high. Just watch your feet, then procede to the right.
content.protection: 2 pads.
content.location:
Down by the creek about a 80 yards from

Afro Bush

.

content.description:
This is one of those silly little problems that can be easily overlooked as something short and easy.  While it is short, it's not really that easy... and it's quite fun.

Start matched low in underclings and move past desperate slopers to a final jug hold.
content.protection: A pad or two.
content.location:
This is on the seventh tier of boulders down the streambed from the

Hydrahedral

. This is by

Kandy Korn

and a proud, undone highball.

content.description: Start with left hand on bottom hold of the far left arete and the jugs under the roof. Heel hooking is also helpful.
content.protection: Only needs about 2 pads.
content.location: North side of the creek up in the woods. I know this isn't very descriptive, but we don't have much to work with.

content.description: Stand start the vertical face to the slabby topout.
content.protection: 2 pads, one spot.
content.location: This is on Tier 2 just west of the large Grey Whale Boulder. It faces east and is to the left of "V9'ish' Arete"

content.description:
This is 6 feet right of

Afro Bush

.  SDS, long move right hand to good edge, left hand to

Afro Bush

jug, big move to good hold.  Trend left to same finish as

Afro Bush

.
content.protection: There is a safe sandy landing. A couple of pads make it pretty cush.
content.location:
This is in the

Afro Bush

grotto.

content.description: Steep wall facing the trail.  Start low and right, move left via a dynamic move to a sharp flake, then back right to a semi-dangerous topout.
content.protection: 3-4+ pads, there is a pretty good pit below this thing....
content.location: Bear Canyon Trail, ~30 feet above trail.  Just up and left from Trailhedral Rock.

climbs.name: Bear Trap
climbs.fa: Ned Harris, 2009? SDS Late Sept 2011 Matt Ray

content.description:
This uses a stand up start.  There is a hard move off the ground, go over a bulge, rock over left using pebble out left, use nice holds to finish, but watch out for the tree.

UPDATE: SDS cleaned by aging boulderer and sent with ease by climber 20 years younger.  SDS starts laying down matched on obvious horizontal. Probably in the V7/V8 range and quite good.
content.protection: 2-4 pads/spotters.  Semi higball.
content.location:
This is in the Bear Creek streambed.

It ascends the left side of boulder directly across from the route '

Thought Control

, 5.9'.

content.description: It is about 25-28 moves depending on beta. The bottom section goes at about V8/9 and the top section is around V6/7 to a V3/4 topout. It's one of the most beautiful, proud, and pure lines I have ever done. Please go check it out! It deserves the traffic. I suggest bringing a rope to try the top sections before you go for the send. Enjoy!
content.protection: You can easily set up a top rope on some boulders and a tree at the top of the boulder. Top-roping the upper section is certainly a good idea as it is the redpoint crux.
content.location: This is located in Bear Canyon, in the Flatirons, near Boulder, CO. It lies about 30 meters down the wash from the Afro Bush Boulder. It starts on the lowest jug at the bottom right of the boulder. A few moves directly up lead to a traversing section. Traversing leftwards through the physical crux that ends in a right hand cross into a jug undercling off of a left hand sloper bulge.

content.description:
This thing is too cool not to be described anywhere!  I hope I got the FA info correct (info is per Will L. - who usually knows what's up).

Perhaps the best problem of its grade in the Flatirons.  SDS out steep bulge to a cruxy bit to a jug.  Finish with a classic topout on water polished, Fountain formation sandstone.  So good! Go do it!
content.protection: Gorgeous grotto with a perfect, sandy landing.  2-4 pads/spotters will make it very reasonable.
content.location:
This is in the streambed of Bear Creek.  It is a little tricky to find at first.  A steep social trail leads downhill from the Bear Canyon Trail to the streambed.  If you get to the route '

Thought Control

, 5.9' on the right, you have gone too far.
